importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The first memo was issued on October 15, 2025, establishing a requirement for Pentagon officials to obtain prior approval from the legislative affairs office before engaging with Congress.
The second memo was issued on October 17, 2025, forming a working group to refine guidelines on legislative engagements.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline from October 15 to October 22, 2025, captures the rollout and public reaction to the Pentagon's new communication policies with Congress.

keyTakeAways: Pentagon officials, including the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, must now obtain prior approval from the Department’s Legislative Affairs Office before communicating with Congress.
The new policy was implemented after most Pentagon reporters exited the building in protest of new restrictions on reporting.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Steve Feinberg issued two memos to tighten control over Pentagon messaging to Congress.
The Pentagon claims the policy improves accuracy, responsiveness, and transparency in communication with Congress.
The move appears part of a broader effort by Hegseth to exert tighter control over the Pentagon’s external messaging.
The memos were first reported by Breaking Defense.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In early October 2025, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Steve Feinberg issued two memos requiring Pentagon officials—including the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff—to obtain prior approval from the Department’s Legislative Affairs Office before communicating with Congress. This policy shift, described as a 'pragmatic step' by spokesman Sean Parnell, aims to improve accuracy and transparency in messaging. However, it sparked backlash when most Pentagon reporters chose to leave the building in protest of the new restrictions, suggesting concerns about reduced access to information and media freedom. The move appears part of a broader effort by Hegseth to centralize control over the Pentagon’s external communications, particularly with legislative bodies. The second memo established a working group to further define engagement guidelines, indicating ongoing policy refinement.
title: Pentagon Imposes New Restrictions on Communications with Congress
